ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The class offers a great introduction to German short stories and the literary devices that they use. I gained the ability to analyze and read texts critically.
The course is an excellent overview of German prose. It really helped to improve my German reading, writing, and speaking skills.
I improved my German lots after a long period away, and learnt lots about das Fremde in German literature. Speaking in German and the presentation etc was very useful too.
How to write academically in German, reading German texts.
This course greatly improved my written and spoken German through the study of German literature covering a wide range of periods and topics.
I improved my ability to read, write, and speak German, as well as a much better sense of a wide range of German prose authors (and, to a lesser extent, poets).
My German improved tremendously from reading lots of German texts. My text analysis improved from the weekly writing assignments. Additionally, the content was challenging but always manageable.

This course improved my understanding of the German language and German literature. The course was time-intensive, but by taking this course I improved both my German language skills and my ability to analyze literature in any language.
I learnt how to read complex classic German literature and analyze texts for contemporary themes such as discussions of race, identity and immigration.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Pros
- Shira is an amazing instructor! Her love for the stories is simply infectious. 
- There are no in-class exams

Cons
- We wasted so much time with the student presentations. We should ideally have spent only 5-10 minutes on the student presentations before moving on to the more interesting class discussion. 
- There is too much homework. There should be one homework assignment per story.
- Some stories take up 3 sessions. This is too much time for one story. Each story should have a maximum of 2 sessions to make room for more stories, especially those published after 1945.

There was quite a lot of work. It was good for me because honestly I needed it to get back up to a high level of German, but I anticipated it being less and some of the readings in German were quite long.
This is an amazing course. It's very fast paced, but you learn a lot.

Although the texts explored by the course spanned multiple centuries, they were tied together well by the course topic, "Das Fremde". Shira masterfully facilitated advanced discussions of the texts, despite the fact that that this was a foreign language seminar. The weekly written and oral responses were quite a bit of work, but completely worth it--our in-class discussions really profited off of them, and my German improved over the course of the semester.

This course was wonderful  Shira's syllabus was well thought-out and ambitious without being unattainable. Frequent reading and oral reflections ensured a steady improvement in my ability to express myself in written and spoken German and helped me focus my reading. The class included a mixture of group-work, presentations by peers and the instructor, and seminar-style conversation, which always made the class feel fresh and facilitated sustained engagement. Longer-term assignments gave us the freedom to engage very deeply with texts we were interested and learn to express nuanced thoughts in German.

The strengths of this course was the amount of content to read assigned. We often read 10-20 pages per class, which was a good amount considering the difficulty of some texts. Another strength was the variety of texts.

The course was time-intensive, but Professor Miron is an amazing instructor and she put a lot of time into the course, too. By taking this course I improved both my German language skills and my ability to analyze literature in any language. There is nothing I would change about this course.

This course had a great selection of texts that all explored the theme of Fremdsein or the Foreign in interesting ways, therefore allowing us to build on our understanding of the concept in each text. The weekly seminar discussions really helped us to practice how to discuss themes with each other in German, and the instructor gave a presentation on the main themes for that selected text that week.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! This class offers an excellent survey of German literature.

I would recommend this course to any student who is interested in gaining an overall understanding of German prose literature, as well as practicing close reading and working with secondary sources in the papers.
Absolutely if youre trying to major in German, get the certificate or are just interested. Class discussions were great and lots of the material was very fun to read.
Absolutely.
Yes, I would! The texts we read were always fun to read, and Shira was a wonderful discussion leader.
Yes! It was a great opportunity to experience a fascinating literature seminar conducted in German.
Yes. This is my favorite German course and perhaps favorite overall course I have taken at Yale.

If you are interested in German literature and in improving your German, then absolutely. This was my favorite class this termProfessor Miron is an amazing and engaged instructor, and I learned a lot about German literature and the German language.
I would highly recommend this course to any student that wants to learn how to closely and critically read German literature.
